elements.content: Increasing the number of chiral centers by adjusting auxiliary coligands results in a heterometallic metamagnet with a three-dimensional homochiral framework containing both cyanide and dicyanamide bridges.
elements.clean_text: Increasing the number of chiral centers by adjusting auxiliary coligands results in a heterometallic metamagnet with a three-dimensional homochiral framework containing both cyanide and dicyanamide bridges.

elements.content: The first three-dimensional heterometallic metamagnet containing cyanide and dicyanamide bridges with homochirality based on [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]- was achieved through an approach of increasing the number of different chiral centers by adjusting auxiliary coligands.
elements.clean_text: The first three-dimensional heterometallic metamagnet containing cyanide and dicyanamide bridges with homochirality based on [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]- was achieved through an approach of increasing the number of different chiral centers by adjusting auxiliary coligands.

elements.content: The design of chiral magnetic materials for combining magnetism and optical activity has been of active interest in recent years. Especially, great efforts in constructing high-dimensional homochiral molecular magnets with long-range ordering have been prompted by the possibility of observing stronger magnetochiral dichroism (MChD). In this regard, materials based on short bridges of oxalate (C2O4 2-, ox), cyanide (CN-), or azide (N3 -), the most effective mediators of magnetic couplings, are studied much more. A series of chiral ox-bridged compounds have been reported through [M(ox)3]3- blocks. Inoue and Gao have achieved some interesting chiral magnets bridged by hexacyanometalates or azides through two representative approaches:  stereoselective synthesis using chiral species and spontaneous resolution upon crystallization with an achiral auxiliary, respectively. Among the reported chiral magnets, cyano-bridged ones might be all-important because of the highest ordering temperatures. However, it is still an open challenge in constructing new ones by spontaneous resolution because of the serendipitous and unclear self-organization processes at present.
elements.clean_text: The design of chiral magnetic materials for combining magnetism and optical activity has been of active interest in recent years. Especially, great efforts in constructing high-dimensional homochiral molecular magnets with long-range ordering have been prompted by the possibility of observing stronger magnetochiral dichroism (MChD). In this regard, materials based on short bridges of oxalate (C2O4 2-, ox), cyanide (CN-), or azide (N3 -), the most effective mediators of magnetic couplings, are studied much more. A series of chiral ox-bridged compounds have been reported through [M(ox)3]3- blocks. Inoue and Gao have achieved some interesting chiral magnets bridged by hexacyanometalates or azides through two representative approaches: stereoselective synthesis using chiral species and spontaneous resolution upon crystallization with an achiral auxiliary, respectively. Among the reported chiral magnets, cyano-bridged ones might be all-important because of the highest ordering temperatures. However, it is still an open challenge in constructing new ones by spontaneous resolution because of the serendipitous and unclear self-organization processes at present.

elements.content: As mentioned previously, chiral units could be formed from achiral components simply by coordination or better by chelates. In the investigation on the cyano-bridged Cr−Mn system based on building blocks [Cr(L)(CN)4]- (L = phen or 2,2‘-bpy), we also found that, although no chiral compounds were obtained, chiral units (such as dinuclear of [Cr1Mn1]) based on more than one auxiliary coligand did exist in the reported compounds, indicating possible chiral induction through the [Cr(L)(CN)4]- units. However, the units were racemic by an inversion center in all of the compounds. Thus, the question is, how does one reduce the centrosymmetric probability and then extend (“transfer”) chirality into high dimensions?
elements.clean_text: As mentioned previously, chiral units could be formed from achiral components simply by coordination or better by chelates. In the investigation on the cyano-bridged Cr-Mn system based on building blocks [Cr(L)(CN)4]- (L = phen or 2,2‘-bpy), we also found that, although no chiral compounds were obtained, chiral units (such as dinuclear of [Cr1Mn1]) based on more than one auxiliary coligand did exist in the reported compounds, indicating possible chiral induction through the [Cr(L)(CN)4]- units. However, the units were racemic by an inversion center in all of the compounds. Thus, the question is, how does one reduce the centrosymmetric probability and then extend ("transfer") chirality into high dimensions?

elements.content: Although we have obtained a zigzag chain of {Mn(dca)(bpy)(H2O)[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]·H2O} n (A), the remarkable coordination diversities of the dicyanamide (N(CN)2 -, dca) ligand as well as its asymmetric character, which might be propitious to chiral induction and transfer, still attracted our further investigation on the [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]-/MnII/bpy/dca- system in detail. As a result, three new compounds [{Mn(bpy)(dca)(H2O)2[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]}·CH3OH (1), {Mn(dca)(H2O)2[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]} n ·2nH2O (2), and {Mn(bpy)0.5(dca)[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]} n (3)] were obtained. Among them, compound 3 shows a three-dimensional (3D) homochiral framework. Herein, we report their synthesis, structures, and magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: Although we have obtained a zigzag chain of {Mn(dca)(bpy)(H2O)[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]⋅H2O} n  (A), the remarkable coordination diversities of the dicyanamide (N(CN)2 -, dca) ligand as well as its asymmetric character, which might be propitious to chiral induction and transfer, still attracted our further investigation on the [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]-/MnII/bpy/dca- system in detail. As a result, three new compounds [{Mn(bpy)(dca)(H2O)2[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]}⋅CH3OH (1), {Mn(dca)(H2O)2[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]} n ⋅2nH2O (2), and {Mn(bpy)0.5(dca)[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]} n  (3)] were obtained. Among them, compound 3 shows a three-dimensional (3D) homochiral framework. Herein, we report their synthesis, structures, and magnetic properties.

elements.content: 1 consists of a neutral molecular dinuclear entity of {Mn(bpy)(H2O)2(dca)[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]} and lattice methanol molecules (Figure a). The CrIII ion chelated by one bpy is coordinated to four cyanide groups and connects to the octahedral MnII ion through one cyanide group (∠Mn1N1⋮C1 = 165.3°). The other sites of the MnII ion are occupied by another bpy, two water molecules, and one terminal dca ligand, respectively. The dinuclear unit itself is chiral, but heterochiral units are centrosymmetrically linked into a 3D crystal structure in space group P1̄ via H bonds between the dinuclear units (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: 1 consists of a neutral molecular dinuclear entity of {Mn(bpy)(H2O)2(dca)[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]} and lattice methanol molecules (Figure a). The CrIII ion chelated by one bpy is coordinated to four cyanide groups and connects to the octahedral MnII ion through one cyanide group (∠Mn1N1⋮C1 = 165.3°). The other sites of the MnII ion are occupied by another bpy, two water molecules, and one terminal dca ligand, respectively. The dinuclear unit itself is chiral, but heterochiral units are centrosymmetrically linked into a 3D crystal structure in space group P1̄ via H bonds between the dinuclear units (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: View of the structure of (a) a dinuclear unit of1, (b) a 3,3‘-ladder-like chain of 2, and (c) a homochiral 3,3‘-ladder-like chain along the bc plane of 3.
elements.clean_text: 1  View of the structure of (a) a dinuclear unit of1, (b) a 3,3‘-ladder-like chain of 2, and (c) a homochiral 3,3‘-ladder-like chain along the bc plane of 3.

elements.content: The structure of 2 consists of neutral cyano-bridged bimetallic 3,3‘ ladders of {Mn(dca)(H2O)2Cr(bpy)(CN)4} n (Figure b), similar to that of compound {Mn(N3)(CH3OH)(H2O)[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]·2H2O} n , where azide ligands are now replaced by terminal dca ligands. Each [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]- unit connects to three octahedral MnII ions in mer geometry, and correspondingly each MnII ion is linked to three CrIII ions by cyanide bridges, thus forming a planar ladder along the b axis. The other three sites of Mn1 are occupied by one Ndca (N7) and two Owater (O1 and O2) atoms with Mn−Ndca = 2.19 Å and Mn−Ncyanide = 2.23−2.25 Å. Again, upon coordination, the dinuclear [Mn(dca)(H2O)2Cr(bpy)(CN)4] unit is chiral but is heterochirally linked to the neighboring ones by the inversion center in the ladder. The Cr−Mn distances in the rungs and legs are slightly different, with 5.37 and 5.45−5.48 Å, respectively. The shortest interladder Cr−Cr, Cr−Mn, and Mn−Mn distances are ca. 8.0 Å. The ladders and lattice water molecules form a 3D crystal structure through lots of H bonds (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The structure of 2 consists of neutral cyano-bridged bimetallic 3,3‘ ladders of {Mn(dca)(H2O)2Cr(bpy)(CN)4} n  (Figure b), similar to that of compound {Mn(N3)(CH3OH)(H2O)[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]⋅2H2O} n , where azide ligands are now replaced by terminal dca ligands. Each [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]- unit connects to three octahedral MnII ions in mer geometry, and correspondingly each MnII ion is linked to three CrIII ions by cyanide bridges, thus forming a planar ladder along the b axis. The other three sites of Mn1 are occupied by one Ndca (N7) and two Owater (O1 and O2) atoms with Mn-Ndca = 2.19 Å and Mn-Ncyanide = 2.23-2.25 Å. Again, upon coordination, the dinuclear [Mn(dca)(H2O)2Cr(bpy)(CN)4] unit is chiral but is heterochirally linked to the neighboring ones by the inversion center in the ladder. The Cr-Mn distances in the rungs and legs are slightly different, with 5.37 and 5.45-5.48 Å, respectively. The shortest interladder Cr-Cr, Cr-Mn, and Mn-Mn distances are ca. 8.0 Å. The ladders and lattice water molecules form a 3D crystal structure through lots of H bonds (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Compound 3 shows a novel homochiral 3D framework in space group P1. As shown in Figure c, the asymmetric unit, a chiral tetranuclear entity of {Mn2(bpy)(dca)2[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]2}, includes two unique CrIII ions (Cr1 and Cr2) and two MnII ions (Mn1 and Mn2). [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]- units and octahedral MnII ions are connected to each other in the same mode in 2, giving a bc-planar 3,3‘-ladder-like chain along the b axis. Each Cr1 links two Mn1 and one Mn2 ions, while each Cr2 connects two Mn2 and one Mn1 ions; thus, the two unique dinuclear units, [Cr1−Mn1] and [Cr2−Mn2], repeat, homochirally, along one leg of the ladder and along the other, respectively. The rest of the three coordination sites of Mn1 are completed by one bpy and one dca bridge (Mn1−N15 = 2.16 Å), while those of Mn2 by three dca bridges [Mn2−N17B(N18C, N20) ≈ 2.22 Å]. Thus, each Mn1 as a 4-connection site is further linked to one Mn2 ion of a neighboring ladder through a μ1,5-dca bridge, giving a homochiral two-dimensional sheet in the bc plane, which is homochirally extended into the final 3D structure by μ1,5-dca bridges from the 6-connected Mn2 ions (Figures and S3 in the Supporting Information). The dca-bridged Mn···Mn separations are 8.50 Å (Mn1···Mn2) and 8.73 Å (Mn2···Mn2), which are similar to those previously reported through μ1,5-dca bridges.
elements.clean_text: Compound 3 shows a novel homochiral 3D framework in space group P1. As shown in Figure c, the asymmetric unit, a chiral tetranuclear entity of {Mn2(bpy)(dca)2[Cr(bpy)(CN)4]2}, includes two unique CrIII ions (Cr1 and Cr2) and two MnII ions (Mn1 and Mn2). [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]- units and octahedral MnII ions are connected to each other in the same mode in 2, giving a bc-planar 3,3‘-ladder-like chain along the b axis. Each Cr1 links two Mn1 and one Mn2 ions, while each Cr2 connects two Mn2 and one Mn1 ions; thus, the two unique dinuclear units, [Cr1-Mn1] and [Cr2-Mn2], repeat, homochirally, along one leg of the ladder and along the other, respectively. The rest of the three coordination sites of Mn1 are completed by one bpy and one dca bridge (Mn1-N15 = 2.16 Å), while those of Mn2 by three dca bridges [Mn2-N17B(N18C, N20) ~ 2.22 Å]. Thus, each Mn1 as a 4-connection site is further linked to one Mn2 ion of a neighboring ladder through a μ1,5-dca bridge, giving a homochiral two-dimensional sheet in the bc plane, which is homochirally extended into the final 3D structure by μ1,5-dca bridges from the 6-connected Mn2 ions (Figures and S3 in the Supporting Information). The dca-bridged Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn separations are 8.50 Å (Mn1⋅⋅⋅Mn2) and 8.73 Å (Mn2⋅⋅⋅Mn2), which are similar to those previously reported through μ1,5-dca bridges.

elements.content: View of a homochiral 3D structure of3 bridged by cyanide and μ1,5-dca ligands. (All bpy molecules are omitted for clarity.)
elements.clean_text: 2  View of a homochiral 3D structure of3 bridged by cyanide and μ1,5-dca ligands. (All bpy molecules are omitted for clarity.)

elements.content: It is noteworthy that our synthetic strategy is mainly based on the coordination abilities of the different auxiliary coligands (bpy > dca > H2O). Thus, the rational decrease of bpy (half the amount, which released half the amount of Mn2+ ions for dca ligands) plays a crucial role in the formation of 3, successfully inducing two different Mn sites, Mn1 ([Mn(bpy)(NC)3(dca)]) and Mn2 ([Mn(NC)3(dca)3]), and thus leading to a chirally binded tetranuclear unit [Cr1Mn1Cr2Mn2]. Compared with A, 1, and 2, where only one dinuclear chiral unit ([Cr1Mn1]) exists, obviously, the centrosymmetric probability between the tetracenter units in 3 could reduce greatly. As a result, 3 represents a new example of chiral induction and transfer, from mixed achiral ligands to chiral tetranuclear units, to homochiral ladders by cyanide, and finally to 3D chiral framework by dca bridges. It seems that increasing the number of potential chiral centers in the unit by adjusting auxiliary coligands would be of benefit to the formation of chiral structures, and this has merit for further investigation.
elements.clean_text: It is noteworthy that our synthetic strategy is mainly based on the coordination abilities of the different auxiliary coligands (bpy > dca > H2O). Thus, the rational decrease of bpy (half the amount, which released half the amount of Mn2+ ions for dca ligands) plays a crucial role in the formation of 3, successfully inducing two different Mn sites, Mn1 ([Mn(bpy)(NC)3(dca)]) and Mn2 ([Mn(NC)3(dca)3]), and thus leading to a chirally binded tetranuclear unit [Cr1Mn1Cr2Mn2]. Compared with A, 1, and 2, where only one dinuclear chiral unit ([Cr1Mn1]) exists, obviously, the centrosymmetric probability between the tetracenter units in 3 could reduce greatly. As a result, 3 represents a new example of chiral induction and transfer, from mixed achiral ligands to chiral tetranuclear units, to homochiral ladders by cyanide, and finally to 3D chiral framework by dca bridges. It seems that increasing the number of potential chiral centers  in the unit by adjusting auxiliary coligands would be of benefit to the formation of chiral structures, and this has merit for further investigation.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 1−3 were investigated (Figures and S4 in the Supporting Information). Their magnetic susceptibilities (per [MnCr] unit) above 50 K obey the Curie−Weiss law with the Curie (C) and Weiss (θ) constants:  C = 6.3 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = −19.5 K for 1; C = 6.6 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = −46 K for 2; and C = 6.4 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = −43 K for 3, respectively. The C values are in good agreement with the calculated value of 6.25 expected for a sum of isolated spin-only ions for MnIICrIII (g = 2). The negative Weiss constants indicate an overall antiferromagnetic (AF) interaction between CrIII and MnII ions. The data of 1 were fitted by the dimer model with the best results (H = −JS Cr1·S Mn1, where J and zJ ‘ are the coupling constants through the cyano bridge and intermolecular interaction, respectively):  J = −5.2 cm-1, zJ ‘ = 0.15 cm-1, g = g Cr = g Mn = 2.02 with R = 1.2 × 10-5 {R = ∑[(χM T)obs − (χM T)calc]2/∑(χM T)obs 2}.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic properties of 1-3 were investigated (Figures  and S4 in the Supporting Information). Their magnetic susceptibilities (per [MnCr] unit) above 50 K obey the Curie-Weiss law with the Curie (C) and Weiss (θ) constants: C = 6.3 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = -19.5 K for 1; C = 6.6 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = -46 K for 2; and C = 6.4 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = -43 K for 3, respectively. The C values are in good agreement with the calculated value of 6.25 expected for a sum of isolated spin-only ions for MnIICrIII (g = 2). The negative Weiss constants indicate an overall antiferromagnetic (AF) interaction between CrIII and MnII ions. The data of 1 were fitted by the dimer model with the best results (H = -JS Cr1⋅S Mn1, where J and zJ‘ are the coupling constants through the cyano bridge and intermolecular interaction, respectively): J = -5.2 cm-1, zJ‘ = 0.15 cm-1, g = g Cr = g Mn = 2.02 with R = 1.2 × 10-5 {R = ∑[(χM T)obs - (χM T)calc]2/∑(χM T)obs 2}.

elements.content: χM T vs T in an applied field of 1 kOe for 1 (□), 1 kOe for 2 (▵), and 2 kOe for 3 (·). Inset:  χM vs T plots at different fields for 3.
elements.clean_text: 3  χM T vs T in an applied field of 1 kOe for 1 (□), 1 kOe for 2 (▵), and 2 kOe for 3 (⋅). Inset: χM vs T plots at different fields for 3.

elements.content: Both 2 and 3 are metamagnets. Their χM T values decrease gradually upon cooling, reach minima at about 22 K, and then increase abruptly, indicating a ferrimagnetic-like character, which might be due to the noncompensation between the AF-coupled spins of the MnII and CrIII ions in the ladders. The further sharp decreases after the maxima at about 14 and 16 K, respectively, might be caused by the magnetic saturation and/or AF interactions between the ladders. Long-range orderings were confirmed by field-cooled magnetizations (FCMs) and ac susceptibilities at different frequencies of 277−4111 Hz in a zero dc field (Figures S5−S7 in the Supporting Information). The FCMs at 100 Oe for 2 (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information) and at 20 Oe for 3 (inset of Figure ) and the real parts of ac susceptibilities display maxima at about 3 and 9 K, respectively, while the out-of-phase component (χ‘ ‘) remains zero, clearly indicating the occurrence of 3D AF ordering. The transition temperatures (T N) were estimated as 2.8 K (for 2) and 9 K (for 3) by the peak of χac vs T. The maxima in χM vs T plots gradually disappear when the applied fields are increased, suggesting a metamagnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text: Both 2 and 3 are metamagnets. Their χM T values decrease gradually upon cooling, reach minima at about 22 K, and then increase abruptly, indicating a ferrimagnetic-like character, which might be due to the noncompensation between the AF-coupled spins of the MnII and CrIII ions in the ladders. The further sharp decreases after the maxima at about 14 and 16 K, respectively, might be caused by the magnetic saturation and/or AF interactions between the ladders. Long-range orderings were confirmed by field-cooled magnetizations (FCMs) and ac susceptibilities at different frequencies of 277-4111 Hz in a zero dc field (Figures S5-S7 in the Supporting Information). The FCMs at 100 Oe for 2 (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information) and at 20 Oe for 3 (inset of Figure ) and the real parts of ac susceptibilities display maxima at about 3 and 9 K, respectively, while the out-of-phase component (χ‘‘) remains zero, clearly indicating the occurrence of 3D AF ordering. The transition temperatures (T N) were estimated as 2.8 K (for 2) and 9 K (for 3) by the peak of χac vs T. The maxima in χM vs T plots gradually disappear when the applied fields are increased, suggesting a metamagnetic behavior.

elements.content: The sigmoid-shaped field-dependent magnetization at 1.8 K shows that a field-induced metamagnetic transition occurs from an AF state to a ferrimagnetic state, where the magnetization value is 2.21 Nβ/mol at 70 kOe and 1.8 K for 2 and 2.01 Nβ/mol at 50 kOe and 1.9 K for 3, consistent with the expected ferrimagnetic state with S T = 5/2 − 3/2 = 1 for the [MnCr] unit (Figure ). The critical field (H c) is ca. 0.75 kOe for 2 at 1.8 K, greatly lower than that of 3 with 7.5 kOe, estimated from the sharp peak of dM/dH vs H. As expected, the sigmoidal feature of the magnetization curves gradually disappears at 5 and 10 K for 3.
elements.clean_text: The sigmoid-shaped field-dependent magnetization at 1.8 K shows that a field-induced metamagnetic transition occurs from an AF state to a ferrimagnetic state, where the magnetization value is 2.21 Nβ/mol at 70 kOe and 1.8 K for 2 and 2.01 Nβ/mol at 50 kOe and 1.9 K for 3, consistent with the expected ferrimagnetic state with S T = 5/2 - 3/2 = 1 for the [MnCr] unit (Figure ). The critical field (H c) is ca. 0.75 kOe for 2 at 1.8 K, greatly lower than that of 3 with 7.5 kOe, estimated from the sharp peak of dM/dH vs H. As expected, the sigmoidal feature of the magnetization curves gradually disappears at 5 and 10 K for 3.

elements.content: Field dependence of magnetization (a) for2 at 1.8 K and (b) for 3 at 1.9, 5, and 10 K, respectively. Inset:  low-field region.
elements.clean_text: 4  Field dependence of magnetization (a) for2 at 1.8 K and (b) for 3 at 1.9, 5, and 10 K, respectively. Inset: low-field region.

elements.content: It is reasonable that 3 as well as 2 shows metamagnetism because of different intraladder (cyano bridge) and interladder (through H bonds for 2 and a dca bridge for 3) interactions. Moreover, although the interladder distances of 3 are slightly longer than those of 2, the μ1,5-dca bridges exhibit more effective pathways in mediating magnetic coupling, leading to higher H c and T N.
elements.clean_text: It is reasonable that 3 as well as 2 shows metamagnetism because of different intraladder (cyano bridge) and interladder (through H bonds for 2 and a dca bridge for 3) interactions. Moreover, although the interladder distances of 3 are slightly longer than those of 2, the μ1,5-dca bridges exhibit more effective pathways in mediating magnetic coupling, leading to higher H c and T N.

elements.content: In summary, we synthesized a series of cyano/dca-coordinated compounds based on the [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]- unit as well as the different coordination abilities of bpy and dca. The insufficiency of bpy leads to the first 3D metamagnet (3) containing both cyanide and dca bridges, which is also a new example of chiral induction and transfer, from achiral components to homochiral solids. The present result indicates that increasing the number of potential chiral centers in the molecular unit by adjusting auxiliary coligands seems to be an effective way of avoiding heterochiraliy and undergoing spontaneous resolution.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we synthesized a series of cyano/dca-coordinated compounds based on the [Cr(bpy)(CN)4]- unit as well as the different coordination abilities of bpy and dca. The insufficiency of bpy leads to the first 3D metamagnet (3) containing both cyanide and dca bridges, which is also a new example of chiral induction and  transfer, from achiral components to homochiral solids. The present result indicates that increasing the number of potential chiral centers in the molecular unit by adjusting auxiliary coligands seems to be an effective way of avoiding heterochiraliy and undergoing spontaneous resolution.

metadata.title:
Three-Dimensional Heterometallic Chiral Cr−Mn Compound Constructed
by Cyanide and Dicyanamide Bridges
